1 Probability

1

1.1 Definition of Probability

3

The term probability refers to the study of randomness and uncertainty. In any situation in which one of a number of possible outcomes may occur, the discipline of probability provides methods for quantifying the chances, or likeli- hoods, associated with the various outcomes. (Devore p 50)

undefined
5

Given an experiment and a sample space S, the objective of probability is to assign to each event A a number P(A), called the probability of the event A, which will give a precise measure of the chance that A will occur. (Devore p 55)

undefined
7

1.2 Experiment

9

An experiment is any activity or process whose outcome is subject to uncertainty. ‚Ä¶

undefined

Thus experiments that may be of interest include tossing a coin once or several times, selecting a card or cards from a deck, weighing a loaf of bread, ascertaining the commuting time from home to work on a particular morning, obtaining blood types from a group of individuals, or measuring the compressive strengths of different steel beams. (Devore p 51)

undefined
11-13

An experiment is any process, real or hypothetical, in which the possible outcomes can be identified ahead of time. (DeGroot p 5)

undefined
15

1.3 Sample Space, S (or Event Space)

17

‚Ä¶ the set of all possible outcomes of an experiement. (Devore p 51)

undefined
19

The outcomes in a sample space are noted using the shorthand

21

S={outcome 1, outcome 2, ‚Ä¶}

23

For example, if the experiment is tossing a coin twice and counting the number of heads and tails, the three simple events are 1H1T,2T,2H, and the sample space is

25

S= {1H1T, 2T, 2H}

27

If the experiment is tossing a coin twice and writing down the result of the first toss in box 1 and the result of the second toss in box 2,

29

S= {HH, HT, TH, TT}

31

We can define a compound event: A is the outcome of the experiment yielding one tail.

33

1.4 Event

35

An event is any collection (subset) of outcomes contained in the sample space S. An event is simple if it consists of exactly one outcome and compound if it consists of more than one outcome. (Devore p 52)

undefined
37

An event is just a set. (Devore p 53)

undefined
39

An event is a well-defined set of possible outcomes of the experiment. (DeGroot p 5)

undefined
41

Can we also say a sample space is the set of all possible simple events?

43

47

‚ÄúNot A‚Äù is represented by four symbols: A‚Ä≤ A  A ¬¨A

49

The complement of an event A, denoted by A‚Ä≤, is the set of all outcomes in S that are not contained in A. (Devore p 53)

53

(Rozanov p 14): A‚àíB means the event in which A occurs but not B.

1.5.3 Subset

57

(Rozanov p 15): A‚äÇB means the set A is a subset of B.

1.5.4 Union

61

‚ÄúOr‚Äù (union; inclusive or) is typically represented by ‚à™

63

The union of two events A and B, denoted by A‚à™B ‚ÄúA or B‚Äù is the event consisting of all outcomes that are either in A or in B or in both events (so that the union includes outcomes for which both A and B occur as well as outcomes for which exactly one occurs) ‚Äì that is, all outcomes in at least one of the events. (Devore p 53)

1.5.5 XOR

67

XOR ‚Äì ‚ÄúExclusive or‚Äù: A‚äïB means the event that is in A or B, but not both.

1.5.6 Intersection

71

‚ÄúAnd‚Äù (intersect) is represented by four symbols: ‚à© & , $$

73

The intersection of two events A and B, denoted by A‚à©B and read ‚ÄúA and B,‚Äù is the event consisting of all outcomes that are in both A and B. (Devore p 53)

    Corallary

1.9 Geometric Series

103

a+ar+ar2+...=1‚àíra‚Äã

105

In an experiment where the event is either true (with probability 1‚àíp) or false (with probability p) and we run experiments until we get a false, the sample space of all experiments is E1‚Äã=F, E2‚Äã=TF, E3‚Äã=TTF, ‚Ä¶ and by Axiom 3.

1.10 Relative Frequency and Interpretation of Proability

118

‚Ä¶ most frequently used an most easily understood is based on the notation of relative frequencies. (Devore p 57)

undefined
120

Repeat experiment n times (each repetition is called a ‚Äúreplication‚Äù). If event A occurs n(A) times in n replications, then relative frequency is n(A)/n.

122

The objective interpretation of probability identifies this limiting relative frequency to P(A). (Devore p 57)

undefined
124

Said another way,

126

P(A)=n‚Üí‚àûlim‚Äãnn(A)‚Äã

128

If exeriment is not repeatable, prior information must be used to determine P(A) and not everyone may conclude the same P(A); in this case P(A) has a subjective interpretation. See DeGroot 2012 and Ross 2022 for a discussion of interpretations of probability.

130

Python example of Figure 2.2 Devore:

132

1
2
a = [0, 1]
3
4
# Experiment: Randomly select an element from the list a
5
result = random.choice(a)
6
7
# Repeat the experiment n times
8
n = 2
9
results = []
10
for exp in range(1, n+1):
11
  result = random.choice(a)
12
  results.append(result)
13
14
print(f"n = {n} experiments:")
15
print(f"  Results: {results}")
16
print(f"  rf(0) = {results.count(0) / n}")
17
print(f"  rf(1) = {results.count(1) / n}")

    215

1.15 Product Rule (or Law of Multiplication)

222

(Devore does not name but gives as proposition on p 65)

224

If the first element or object of an ordered pair can be selected in n1‚Äã ways, and for each of these n1‚Äã ways the second element of the pair can be selected in n2‚Äã ways, then the number of pairs is n1‚Äãn2‚Äã. (Devore p 65)

1.18 General Product Rule (or Product Rule for k-Tuples)

236

Suppose a set consists of ordered collections of k elements (k-tuples) and that there are n1‚Äã possible choices for the first element; for each choice of the first element, there are n2‚Äã possible choices of the second element; ‚Ä¶; for each possible choice of the first k‚àí1 elements, there are nk‚Äã choices of the kth element. Then there are n1‚Äãn2‚Äã...nk‚Äã possible k-tuples. (Devore p 66).

undefined
238

Note that ‚Äúelements‚Äù is used here, but in definition of tuple, objects is used.

1.19 Permutation

242

An ordered arrangement of distinct objects, where each arrangement has no duplicate objects. Usually relevant in problems that involve ‚Äúwithout replacement‚Äù.

244

Suppose you have n distinct objects and you want to put them in boxes labeled 1, 2, ‚Ä¶, k. You select one object and put it in the first box. You select a second object from the remaining n‚àí1 objects and put it in box 2, ‚Ä¶.

246

The number of ways to do this is denoted Pk,n‚Äã (or n‚ÄãPk‚Äã) and is

248

Pk,n‚Äã=(n‚àík)!n!‚Äã=n‚ãÖ(n‚àí1)...‚ãÖ(n‚àík)=n‚ãÖ(n‚àí1)‚ãÖ(n‚àí2)...‚ãÖ(n‚àík)‚ãÖ(n‚àík‚àí1)...1n‚ãÖ(n‚àí1)‚ãÖ(n‚àí2)...‚ãÖ(n‚àík)‚ãÖ(n‚àík‚àí1)...1‚Äã

250

Do see this, consider

252

6‚ãÖ5‚ãÖ4=6‚ãÖ5‚ãÖ4‚ãÖ3‚ãÖ2‚ãÖ16‚ãÖ5‚ãÖ4‚ãÖ3‚ãÖ2‚ãÖ1‚Äã

1.20 Combination (un-ordered subset)

256

The number of unique k‚Äìtuples if k‚Äìtuples with the same elements (but in a different order) are treated as the same. In the team picking example, there are 3 team combinations.

258

Each permutation can be regarded as group of k. If we regard a group as equivalent if they have the same elements, then there are fewer groups than permuations. For example, if the two permutations

260

(1,2)

262

(2,1)

264

are regarded as equivalent, then there is only one group containing the numbers 1 and 2. To determine the number of possible orderings of each permutation, ask how many ways a set of k elements can be arranged. The answer is k!.

266

So, to find the number of combinations, divide the number of permutations by k!.

268

Cn,k‚Äã=k!Pn,k‚Äã‚Äã=k!(n‚àík)!n!‚Äã‚Äã=k!(n‚àík)!n!‚Äã

270

Cn,k‚Äã is often called a binomial coefficient and the denoted by (kN‚Äã) and referred to as ‚Äún choose k‚Äù.

272

1.21 Conditional Probability

274

We want to know the probability of event A given event B occured. One way to do this is by counting writing down how we expect the number of times A occured given event B occured in terms of set operations.

276

n(A‚à£B)=n(A‚à©B)+n(A‚Ä≤‚à©B)n(A‚à©B)‚Äã

278-280

The numerator is the number of times A and B occured.

282

The denominator is the number of times B occured - it can occur when A did not did not occur.

284

Note that A‚à©B + A‚Ä≤‚à©B are mutually exclusive, so (A‚à©B)‚à™(A‚Ä≤‚à©B)=B, so we can also write

286

n(A‚à£B)=n(B)n(A‚à©B)‚Äã

288-290

Dividing all terms by n and using the definition of probability in terms of relative frequency gives

292

P(A‚à£B)=P(B)P(A‚à©B)‚Äã

294-296

We were given that the probability of a student having a Visa is 0.5; the the probability of a student having a MasterCard is 0.4; and the probability that they have both is 0.25.

298

We were asked to find the probability that the student has a Visa but not MasterCard.

300

How is this different from the statement ‚Äúgiven the student has a Visa, what is the probability that they do not have a MasterCard?‚Äù

302

‚ÄúThe probability that the student has a Visa but not MasterCard‚Äù can be written in terms of a conditional probability: P(M‚Ä≤‚à£V); based on the statement, we know the student has a Visa, so we are given that V is true. We want to find the probability that the student does not have a MasterCard.

304

Using

306

P(A‚à£B)=P(B)P(A‚à©B)‚Äã

308

we need to compute the right-hand side of

310

P(M‚Ä≤‚à£V)=P(V)P(M‚Ä≤‚à©V)‚Äã

312

Based on the Venn diagram, we know P(M‚Ä≤‚à©V)=0.25 and we were given P(V)=0.5, so

314

P(M‚Ä≤‚à£V)=21‚Äã

316

1.22 Bayes‚Äô Rule

1.22.1 Simple Derivation

333

Definition of conditional probability for two events:

335

P(A‚à£B)=P(B)P(A‚à©B)‚Äã

337

Swapping letters gives

339

P(B‚à£A)=P(A)P(B‚à©A)‚Äã

341

The numerators are identical because A‚à©B=B‚à©A. Combining these two equations gives Bayes‚Äô rule.

343

1.22.2 Terminology

345

P(A‚à£B)=P(B‚à£A)P(B)P(A)‚Äã

347-349

  • Posterior: P(B‚à£A) (probability after knowing B occured)

    351

  • Prior: P(A) (probability prior to knowing B occured)

    352

  • Marginal probability: P(B) (why ‚Äúmarginal‚Äù?)

    353

  • Likelihood: conditional probability on right‚Äìhand side, P(B‚à£A)

    354

  • Odds ratio or relative likelihood: P(A)/P(B)

    355
351-355

Other forms of Bayes include

357

posterior = odds ‚ãÖ prior

359

and the proportionality

361

posterior ‚àº liklihood ‚ãÖ prior

363

See also Understanding Bayes Theorem with Ratios, which uses

365

original odds ‚ãÖ evidence adjustment = new odds

367

In medical terminology (see also Wikipedia; notes by ekamperi; and Covid examples: 1 | 2 | 3),

369

  • Sensitivity, Se‚Äã (true positive rate):

    371-372

    P(T+‚à£D+) = (number of true positives)/(n true positives + n false negatives)

    373

    P(T+‚à£D+) = (true positives)/(total number with disease)

    375

    where T+ is a positive test result and D+ means ‚Äúdisease present‚Äù

    377

  • Specificity, Sp‚Äã (true negative rate):

    379-380

    P(T‚àí‚à£D‚àí) = (number of true negatives)/(number of true negatives + number of false positives)

    381

    P(T‚àí‚à£D‚àí) = (number of true negatives)/(total number without disease).

    383

    where T‚àí is a negative test result and D‚àí means ‚Äúdisease present‚Äù

    385

  • Likelihood ratio: (See also The likelihood ratio and its graphical representation): LR(r)=P(r‚à£D+)/P(r‚à£D‚àí), where r is the test result (could be a continuous variable such as ‚ÄúHDL colesterol‚Äù) Then

    387-388

    Post-test odds of D+ = LR(r) ‚ãÖ Pre-test odds of D+

    389

    If r is dichotomous (test result is positive or negative), then

    391

    LR+=P(T+‚à£D+)/P(T+‚à£D‚àí)=Se‚Äã/(1‚àíSp‚Äã)

    393

    and

    395

    LR‚àí=P(T‚àí‚à£D+)/P(T‚àí‚à£D‚àí)=(1‚àíSe‚Äã)/Sp

    397

4 Statistics

642

4.1 Definitions

644

4.1.1 Population

646

‚ÄúAll‚Äù of the data is called the population. A population can be finite or infinite. An example of a finite population is all US citizens. An example of an infinite population are values from a continuous probability density function. (Technically, when you draw a value from a continuous probability distribution, you are actually drawing from a discrete distribution, because there are finite number of values that can be represented as 64‚Äìbit floating point numbers.)

648

4.1.2 Statistic

650

A statistic is any quantity whose value can be calculated from sample data. Prior to obtaining data, there is uncertainty as to what value of any particular statistic will result. Therefore, a statistic is a random variable and will be denoted by an uppercase letter; a lowercase letter is used to represent the calculated or observed value of the statistic. (Devore p 214)

undefined
652

Note that the sample can contain all data, so alternatively, a statistic is a quantity computed based on values in population (the population mean is a statistic).

654

4.1.3 Population statistic

656

A computation based on all values in a population.

658

4.1.4 Sample statistic

660

A computation based on a sample from a population that gives an estimate of the equivalent value that would be obtained if the same computation was performed on the population (see also Devore p214).

662

4.1.5 Random Samples

664

By random samples, we mean a value drawn from a population with a certain probability distribution. In general random samples implies ‚Äúindependent and identically distributed random variables‚Äù (often abbreviated iid).

666

4.1.6 Sampling Distribution

668

When we take a sample from a population and compute a statistc, for example the sample mean, we want to know the uncertainty in the statistic. That is, we want to know the probability distribution of the means. That is, if we repeated the experiment many times, what would be the distribution of the sample means for all experiments. The probability distribution of the test statistic is the sampling distribution.

670

If the sampling distribution is known, we use it to compute error bars on a test statistic. Sampling distributions are also needed for hypothesis testing.

672

In HW 2.3, we derived a sampling distribution numerically. It was found that when n values of X were drawn from a Gaussian distribution with mean Œº and standard deviation œÉ and the statistic

674

X=n1‚Äãi=1‚àën‚ÄãXi‚Äã

676

was computed 10,000 times, 95% of the time the range

678

[X‚àí1.96n‚ÄãœÉ‚Äã , X+1.96n‚ÄãœÉ‚Äã]

680

included Œº. (We say that this range ‚Äútraps‚Äù Œº 95% of the time.) We actually did not need to do the numerical experiement when n is large. We know the expected result from the Central Limit Theorem.

682

684-686

The sampling distribution of a test statistic depends on the equation for the test statistic and the population distribution. There are a limited number of test statistic/population distributions for which we know the exact sampling distribution of the test statistic. Simulation can be used in other cases.

688

4.1.7 Sampling Distribution Simulation

690

See sampling_dists.py

692

4.1.7.1 Parametric Simulation

694

Values are drawn from a population with known pdf and pdf parameters and a sample statistic is computed. This process is repeated many times to create a pdf of the sample statistic.

696

This procedure was used in HWs 2.3, 2.4, and 3.3.

698

Example: Draw n values from N(0,1) and compute x. Repeat ns‚Äã and plot the pdf or histogram of the ns‚Äã x values.

700

This method does not have practical value ‚Äì if you know the distribution and its parameters, you can simply use the analytical equation for the pdf. I generally have students use a parametric simulation to reinforce the idea of the meaning of the sampling distribution of a test statistic ‚Äì that it is a hypothetical distribution that would result if you could do many repeated experiments.

702

4.1.7.2 Bootstrap

704

The definition of the idiom ‚Äúbootstrapping‚Äù is ‚Äúget (oneself or something) into or out of a situation using existing resources.‚Äù

706

4.1.7.3 Parametric Bootstrap

708

Values are drawn from a population with known pdf and unknown pdf parameters and a sample statistic is computed. The parameters of the population pdf are estimated using the sample. The process is to draw n values from a population and compute a sample statistic. Resample the n values with replacement and compute sample statistic again. Repeat the resampling step nb‚Äã times.

710

For small n, ‚Äúclustering‚Äù can occur because a given value can appear more than once in a bootstrap sample. One way to address this is to add a small random value to each value in the bootstrap sample.

712

Example: Draw n values from N(0,1) and compute x and s. Next, draw n values from N(x,s) and compute x‚àó and repeat this process nb‚Äã times.

714

4.1.7.4 Non-parametric bootstrap

716

Values are drawn from a population with unknown pdf (both functional form and its parameters) and a sample statistic is computed.

718

Example: Draw n values from N(0,1) and compute x and s. Next, create a new sample of size n by resampling the n values with replacement and compute x‚àó; repeat the resampling process nb‚Äã times.

720

This procedure was used in HW 4.2.

4.3 Central Limit Theorem

783

See also Devore p 225.

785

The Law of Large Numbers tells use that if we require X to fall in range that we specify around Œº with a probability that we specify, we can find an n value to satisfy our requirement. The central limit theorem says that for large n, X is Gaussian-distributed with mean Œº and standard deviation œÉ/n‚Äã.

787

With the Central Limit theorem, we can make statements such as ‚ÄúI took a sample of n values and computed X. If I took many samples and computed many Xs, 95% of the time the range [X‚àí1.96œÉ/n‚Äã,X+1.96œÉ/n‚Äã] would include (‚Äútrap‚Äù) Œº.

789

The Central Limit Theorem says that for large n, X‚â°n1‚Äã‚àëi=1n‚ÄãXi‚Äã is Gaussian-distributed with mean Œº and standard deviation œÉ/n‚Äã.

791

Important: this theorem (usually) applies even if the distribution of the values used in computing X are not Gaussian‚Äìdistributed.

793-794

With the Central Limit theorem, we can make statements such as ‚ÄúI took a sample of n values and computed X. If I took many samples and computed many Xs, 95% of the time the range [X‚àí1.96œÉ/n‚Äã,X+1.96œÉ/n‚Äã] would include (‚Äútrap‚Äù) Œº.

The above statements are consistent with typical textbook statements such as

804

The real reason for the importance of the normal distribution lies in the central limit theorem which states that the sum of a large number of independent random variables will be approximately normally distributed almost regardless of their individual distributions; any random variable which can be regarded as the sum of a large number of small, independent contributions is thus likely to follow the normal distribution approximately.

The interpretation is that if the probability of a success in a trial is p, then the probability of k successes in N trials is P(k).

923

A common use case for this equation is when an event takes a certain amount of time Œît to occur (e.g., a hurricane or large solar flare). In this case, it makes sense to define a rate parameter which is the number events per unit time, which is Œª=p/Œît, where p is the probability of an event in Œît. This variable corresponds with how we would describe the probability of an event, e.g., on average 0.01 hurricanes occur per day or in 100 days, 1 hurricane will occur.

925

It also make sense to talk not about the number of ‚Äútrials‚Äù, but rather the number of Œîts, where each Œît corresponds to a trial. In this case, we can define a time as t=NŒît. This definition allows us to say ‚Äúgiven 0.01 hurricanes occur per day, what is the probability that 2 hurricanes occur in a month‚Äù.

4.9 Confidence Intervals

1116

Devore p 267

1118

An alternative to reporting a single sensible value for the parameter being estimated is to calcu- late and report an entire interval of plausible values‚Äîan interval estimate or confidence interval (CI). A confidence level of 95% implies that 95% of all samples would give an interval that includes m, or whatever other parame- ter is being estimated, and only 5% of all samples would yield an erroneous interval. The most frequently used confidence levels are 95%, 99%, and 90%. The higher the confidence level, the more strongly we believe that the value of the parameter being estimated lies within the interval (an interpretation of any particular confidence level will be given shortly).

1120
1120

Devore p 270

1122

it is tempting to conclude that Œº is within this fixed interval with probability .95. ‚Ä¶ It is therefore incorrect to write the statement P(Œº lies in (79.3, 80.7)) = .95.

1124

0      1       2      3        4
       aaaaaaaabbbbbbbb

The above statements are Œº is in range (1,2) with probability 0.95 and Œº is in the range (2,3) with probability 0.95. This implies that Œº is in the range (1,3) with probability of 0.95+0.95, which is greater than 1. Clearly the interpretation of confidence intervals as P(Œº lies in (CIl‚Äã,CIu‚Äã))=1‚àíŒ± cannot be correct.

4.10 Hypothesis Test

1180

Devore p 301

1182

The null hypothesis, denoted by H0‚Äã, is the claim that is initially assumed to be true (the ‚Äúprior belief‚Äù claim). The alternative hypothesis, denoted by Ha‚Äã, is the assertion that is contradictory to H0‚Äã.

1183-1186

The null hypothesis will be rejected in favor of the alternative hypothesis only if sample evidence suggests that H0‚Äã is false. If the sample does not strongly contradict H0‚Äã, we will continue to believe in the plausibility of the null hypothesis. The two possible conclusions from a hypothesis-testing analysis are then reject H0‚Äã or fail to reject H0‚Äã.

1183-1186
1183-1186

Devore p 302

1188

H0‚Äã will generally be stated as an equality claim. If Œ∏ denotes the parameter of interest, the null hypothesis will have the form H0‚Äã: Œ∏=Œ∏0‚Äã, where Œ∏0‚Äã is a specified number called the null value of the parameter (value claimed for Œ∏ by the null hypothesis).

1189
1189

Devore p 303

1191

A test procedure is specified by the following:

1192-1196

  1. A test statistic, a function of the sample data on which the decision (reject H0‚Äã or do not reject H0‚Äã) is to be based [example x]

    1192-1196

  2. A rejection region, the set of all test statistic values for which H0‚Äã will be rejected

    1192-1196
1192-1196

The null hypothesis will then be rejected if and only if the observed or computed test statistic value falls in the rejection region.

1192-1196
1192-1196

Devore p 304

1199

A type I error consists of rejecting the null hypothesis H0‚Äã when it is true.

1200-1202

A type II error involves not rejecting H0‚Äã when H0‚Äã is false.

1200-1202
1200-1202

The conclusion drawn from a two-tailed confidence interval is usually the same as the conclusion drawn from a two-tailed hypothesis test. In other words, if the the 95% confidence interval contains the hypothesized parameter, then a hypothesis test at the 0.05 level will almost always fail to reject the null hypothesis. If the 95% confidence interval does not contain the hypothesize parameter, then a hypothesis test at the 0.05 level will almost always reject the null hypothesis.

1204-1206

https://online.stat.psu.edu/stat200/lesson/6/6.6

1204-1206
1204-1206

Summary of Algorithm

1208

  1. Choose a population parameter, Œ∏ that you want to subject to an equality claim (‚Äúnull hypothesis‚Äù, H0‚Äã) of the form Œ∏=Œ∏0‚Äã, where Œ∏0‚Äã is the ‚Äúnull value‚Äù.

    1226-1240

    For example, suppose we want to test the claim that the mean of a population is 1.0; then Œ∏=Œº and Œ∏0‚Äã=1.0 and H0‚Äã is Œº=1.0.

    1226-1240

  2. Choose an alternative hypothesis, Ha‚Äã. For example ŒºÓÄ†=1.0. The ‚Äúrejection region‚Äù described below depends on the alternative hypothesis.

    1226-1240

  3. Find the equation for Œ∏^, an unbiased estimator of Œ∏.

    1226-1240

    For example if we want to test the claim that Œº=1.0, and unbiased estimator of Œº is x, so Œ∏^=x.

    1226-1240

  4. Determine the sampling distribution of Œ∏^. This sampling distribution will depend on the population distribution (which is rarely known). In most textbook examples, the exact sampling distribution is known because the population distribution is assumed to be known. Also, textbook sampling distributions for Œ∏^ are usually from a short list of common distributions: N, t, œá2, F.

    1226-1240

    Example: If population is N(Œº,œÉ), the sampling distribution of Œ∏^=x is N(Œº,œÉ/n‚Äã)

    1226-1240

    Example: If population is N(Œº,œÉ), the sampling distribution of Œ∏^=s2 is n‚àí1œÉ2‚Äãœán‚àí12‚Äã

    1226-1240

  5. Choose a rejection region in the sampling distribution. If the value of Œ∏^ from the sample, Œ∏^sample‚Äã, is in this region, the equality claim will be rejected. The rejection region has associated with it an area, Œ±. If Ha‚Äã is Œ∏ÓÄ†=Œ∏o‚Äã, the rejection region is values of Œ∏^ in the the lower Œ±/2 and upper Œ±/2 region of the sampling distribution.

    1226-1227

    Example:

    1228

    If we assume population is N(Œº=0,œÉ=1) and execute an experiment of drawing n values from it and compute xsample‚Äã, we reject the null that Œº=0 if xsample‚Äã is in the ‚Äúrare‚Äù region of the sampling distribution for x. We do not reject the null hypothesis otherwise.

    1230

    Based on the assumptions about the population distribution and the fact that the sampling distribution of x is N(Œº=0,œÉ=1/n‚Äã) if these assumptions are true, we exect ‚à£xsample‚Äã‚à£>1.96œÉ/n‚Äã to occur in 5% of hypothetical experiments.

    1232

    Based on this example, when we reject, we are claiming ‚Äúif we could repeat the experiment many times and compute many xsample‚Äã values, values in my selected rejection region are rare, so I‚Äôll reject the hypothesis if an expeirment yields an xsample‚Äã is in the rejection region; otherwise, I won‚Äôt reject the null hypothesis‚Äù. Notice that the statements don‚Äôt involve claims that H0‚Äã is true or false. They only involve statements about whether the observation is likely or not. In a similar way, a jury‚Äôs conclusion of ‚Äúguilty of murder‚Äù is a usually a statement that ‚Äúnot guilty‚Äù is unlikely given the information they were presented. The jury rarely has undisputable evidence that the defendent murdered someone; they usually only have information about motive, means, and opportunity.

    1234

    In summary, a hypotheis test has the logic: Given claim + experimental observation, if a given observation is unlikely based what we know about the probability of every possible experimental observation that could occur, reject claim; otherwise, don‚Äôt reject claim (it is tempting to say ‚Äúaccept claim‚Äù, but that is equivalent to making a statement that the claim is true).

    1236

    See also https://online.stat.psu.edu/stat500/lesson/6a/6a.1

    1238
1210-1238

A confidence interval can be framed as a hypothesis test (See also Bulmer p 169). Consider the test

1240

  • H0‚Äã: Œ∏=Œ∏o‚Äã

    1243-1244

  • Ha‚Äã: H0‚ÄãÓÄ†=Œ∏o‚Äã

    1243
1242-1243

  1. Test statistic: Œ∏^, which is an unbiased estimate of Œ∏.

    1246-1248

  2. Rejection region: Œ∏^ of sample outside the CI. For a 95% CI, the region is the values of Œ∏^ associated with the left tail of area 0.025 and the right tail area of 0.975

    1246
1245-1246

We can repeat the above hypothesis test for any Œ∏0‚Äã inside the CI. We will not reject H0‚Äã for any Œ∏0‚Äã in the rejection region.

1248

  • H0‚Äã: Population parameter Œ∏ is inside the CI of Œ∏^sample‚Äã (so Œ∏0‚Äã is any value in the CI).

    1251-1253

  • Ha‚Äã: Population parameter Œ∏ is outside the CI of Œ∏^sample‚Äã.

    1251
1250-1251

Interpretaion

1253

  • ‚ÄúRejecting H0‚Äã‚Äù does not mean H0‚Äã is false. It means H0‚Äã is unlikely, where the unlikelyness threshold is determined by the confidence interval width.

    1263-1266

  • Bulmer, p 165

    1263-1266

    The rejection of a hypothesis at the 5% level does not imply that the probability that the hypothesis is false is 95%; it merely implies that the observed result belongs to a class of results whos overall probability of occurrence, if the null hypothesis is true, is 5%. This provides good reason, in the sense of a rational degreee of belief, for supposing the hypothesis to be false, but no numerical value can be placed upon this degree of belief.

    1263-1266
    1263-1266

  • Sawilowsky, 2011, Statistal Fallacies

    1263-1266

    Confidence intervals have recently been promoted over the use of hypothesis tests for a litany of unsupported reasons. (a) Among its supposed benefits is the assertion that confidence intervals provide more confidence than do hypothesis tests. This is based on the fallacy that confidence intervals are based on some system of probability theory other than that of hypothesis tests, when in fact they are the same. (b) Another prevalent misconception is confidence intervals must be symmetric.

    1263-1266
    1263-1266

  • Statistical tests, P values, confidence intervals, and power: a guide to misinterpretations

    1263-1264
1255-1264

4.11 p value

1266

Devore p 328:

1268

Using the rejection region method to test hypotheses entails first selecting a significance level Œ±. Then after computing the value of the test statistic, the null hypothesis H0‚Äã is rejected if the value falls in the rejection region and is otherwise not rejected. We now consider another way of reaching a conclusion in a hypothesis testing analysis. This alternative approach is based on calculation of a certain probability called a P-value. One advantage is that the P-value provides an intuitive measure of the strength of evidence in the data against H0‚Äã.

1270
1270

Devore p 329:

1272

The P-value is the probability, calculated assuming that the null hypothesis is true, of obtaining a value of the test statistic at least as contradictory to H0‚Äã as the value calculated from the available sample.

1274
1274

Devore p 329:

1276

Beware: The P-value is not the probability that H0‚Äã is true, nor is it an error probability!

1278
1278
